item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #727 ($category_description of list_cats not filtterd) created
item.dc:creator: dmclark

Line 361 of template-functions-category.php should be:

$link .= 'title="' . apply_filters('category_description',$category->category_description) . '"';

item.title: Ticket #726 (atom feed not identified as feed by is_feed()) updated
item.dc:creator: steph-tara
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #726 (atom feed not identified as feed by is_feed()) created
item.dc:creator: steph-tara
item.description:
filter function on the_content (sticking technorati tags at the end of content) is not being activated in atom feed, while it is for the rss feed.

function:

function append_tags($content) {

if (is_feed()) {

$tags_list=get_bunny_tags_list(); $content.=$tags_list;

} return $content;

}

hooked:

add_filter('the_content', 'append_tags');

Seems that the variable identifying the atom feed page as "feed" is not being set correctly.

item.title: Ticket #724 (comment_time() does not pass arg to get_comment_time()) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #724 (comment_time() does not pass arg to get_comment_time()) created
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: In wp-includes/comment-functions.php, the template function comment_time() (which merely echoes the output of get_comment_time()) does not pass along the $d arg to get_comment_time(), preventing customization of the time format.

item.title: Ticket #723 (Other's Drafts should not repeat your drafts) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description:
Better yet, don't even perform the other_drafts query if there are no other authors on the blog that the author can edit.

Patch attached [otherdraft2_edit.php], run against wp-admin/edit.php v1.39

item.title: Ticket #723 (Other's Drafts should not repeat your drafts) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description:
In getting the initial value for $editable, WP has already performed a query that includes post_author != $user_ID. The problem is that if this is a 1-author blog (the admin, user_ID == "1"), $editable will receive an empty initial value. The next line of code makes $editable an array with the single element of "1" if $editable was empty, essentially adding the admin back into the mix as a potential "other draft". A fix would be to simply turn an empty $editable into an empty array instead of an array with an element of "1".

Patch attached [otherdraft_edit.php], run against wp-admin/edit.php v1.39.

item.title: Ticket #723 (Other's Drafts should not repeat your drafts) updated
item.dc:creator: jesuit
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #723 (Other's Drafts should not repeat your drafts) created
item.dc:creator: jesuit
item.description:
On the edit.php page the logged in users drafts show up in both Your Drafts as well as Other's Drafts.

Obviously your drafts should not show up as Other's drafts. Adding AND post_author != $user_ID to the end of the sql select statement for $other_drafts will fix this.

item.title: Changeset [2109]: If post title is not provided, we still need to have a sanitized name ...
item.dc:creator: rboren
item.description: If post title is not provided, we still need to have a sanitized name for use in permalinks. Use the post id. Bug 717.

item.title: Ticket #721 (WP should not use cache-control: no-store) updated
item.dc:creator: Jesse Ruderman
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #721 (WP should not use cache-control: no-store) created
item.dc:creator: Jesse Ruderman
item.description:
Wordpress uses cache-control: no-store on most pages, including the front page of my WP blog. This causes Firefox to not cache the page even for the purpose of using the Back button. As a result, going Back to a Wordpress blog is slow, loses the scroll position, and loses form content.

I assume the intent is not to ensure that users see the newest version when they hit the Back button (that isn't worth the slowness and disorientation), but to ensure that visitors see the newest version when they click a link or bookmark to a blog they have visited recently. I think that can be accomplished using some combination of no-cache (not no-store), must-revalidate, and expires.

item.dc:creator: rboren
item.description: wp_setcookie() and wp_clearcookie(). Set cookies for both siteurl and home if they are not the same. Update cookies whenever home or siteurl change.

item.title: Ticket #720 (RSS feeds currently do not validate) updated
item.dc:creator: saadiq
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #720 (RSS feeds currently do not validate) created
item.dc:creator: saadiq
item.description:
It seems that the_excerpt_rss() no longer escapes html characters regardless of what parameters it is passed. As such, if you have those characters or html in your excerpt then some news readers will balk on your invalid feed.

I've fixed it on my site by adding CDATA tags to the description elements of the rss feeds and to the summary tag of the atom feed.

item.title: Ticket #717 (Warning for empty title) updated
item.dc:creator: orangenormal
item.description: To clarify the second suggestion--an automatically generated title should be used for the permalink structure only, so if the user doesn't want a title for their post, they can leave it blank (and not have it appear on their blog) but still have the URIs as valid.

item.title: Ticket #717 (Warning for empty title) updated
item.dc:creator: orangenormal
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #717 (Warning for empty title) created
item.dc:creator: orangenormal
item.description: The default permalink structure includes the post title in the URI; this is also a very popular choice for those with custom permalink URIs. Unfortunately, sometimes posters forget to type a title for an entry, creating invalid URIs for the permalink, RSS feed, comment form, and other features. I submit that WordPress should either somehow alert the user if a post title is missing, or automatically generate one for the URIs.
